Fedora 41 Fails To install Tracker

Reproducible: Always

This bug appears to have been reported against 'rawhide' during the Fedora Linux 40 development cycle.
Changing version to 40.
This is a tracking bug for F41 Changes.
Created early as we deferred the DNF 5 Change from F39 to F41 and need to track that. Version will need resetting when F40 branches.

This is a tracking bug for Change: Perl 5.40
For more details, see: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/perl5.40

A new perl 5.40 version brings a lot of changes done over a year of development. Perl 5.40 should be released on May 20th 2024. See perldelta for 5.39.9 for more details about new release.

If you encounter a bug related to this Change, please do not comment here. Instead create a new bug and set it to block this bug.

Hi @jplesnik can you provide a status update for this change please? Its required to be testable currently and 100% code complete before we hit Beta freeze next Tuesday 27th August. Please indicate whether this change is on track for F41 development or needs to be re-targeted to F42. Thanks!

(In reply to Aoife Moloney from comment #1)
> Hi @jplesnik can you provide a status update for this change please? Its
> required to be testable currently and 100% code complete before we hit Beta
> freeze next Tuesday 27th August. Please indicate whether this change is on
> track for F41 development or needs to be re-targeted to F42. Thanks!

Hi, the change is code complete and is ready for Fedora 41. It is in Fedora 41 since June and there was not found any big issue. For me, it is done.
Amazing, thanks Jiri!

Fedora 42 Fails To install Tracker


Reproducible: Always
This is a tracking bug for F41 Changes.
Created early as we deferred the DNF 5 Change from F39 to F41 and need to track that. Version will need resetting when F40 branches.
This is a tracking bug for F41 Changes.
Created early as we deferred the DNF 5 Change from F39 to F41 and need to track that. Version will need resetting when F40 branches.

This is a tracking bug for Change: Python built with gcc -O3
For more details, see: https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/Python_built_with_gcc_O3

Instead of Fedora's default -O2 compiler flag, we will use -O3 to build CPython.
This only impacts the interpreter and Python standard library, not any 3rd party extension modules built as RPM or on developer machines.
This aligns with the way Python is built upstream.
According to our performance measurements, it makes Python significantly faster (pyperformance geometric mean: 1.04x faster).

If you encounter a bug related to this Change, please do not comment here. Instead create a new bug and set it to block this bug.
This is now live in Python 3.13. Waiting for Python 3.13 to become the main Python before considering backports to other places.
Python 3.13 is the main Python now.
This is a tracking Bugzilla for Python 3.13-related work.

Hi @ksurma, do you have an update on this change? Has the updates for the Python stack landed yet? We are entering Beta freeze next week so an understanding of this chnages status would be very appreciated. Thank you!

Hi, Python 3.13 is the main Python of Fedora 41 now; the updates have landed. There are still 89 packages in Fedora 41 that have not been rebuilt with Python 3.13 yet.
We plan to update Python to 3.13.0 (planned release date: Oct. 1st 2024). Citing @churchyard from last year: this is testable, but only 99% complete.
Thanks for the update Karolina, much appreciate, I will note this in the changes report to FESCo.

Hello,

Please note that this comment was generated automatically by https://pagure.io/releng/blob/main/f/scripts/ftbfs-fti/follow-policy.py
If you feel that this output has mistakes, please open an issue at https://pagure.io/releng/

Your package (znc) Fails To Install in Fedora 41:

can't install znc-modperl:
  - nothing provides libperl.so.5.38()(64bit) needed by znc-modperl-1.8.2-25.fc40.x86_64
  
If you know about this problem and are planning on fixing it, please acknowledge so by setting the bug status to ASSIGNED. If you don't have time to maintain this package, consider orphaning it, so maintainers of dependent packages realize the problem.


If you don't react accordingly to the policy for FTBFS/FTI bugs (https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/fesco/Fails_to_build_from_source_Fails_to_install/), your package may be orphaned in 8+ weeks.


P.S. The data was generated solely from koji buildroot, so it might be newer than the latest compose or the content on mirrors. To reproduce, use the koji/local repo only, e.g. in mock:

    $ mock -r fedora-41-x86_64 --config-opts mirrored=False install znc-modperl


P.P.S. If this bug has been reported in the middle of upgrading multiple dependent packages, please consider using side tags: https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/fesco/Updates_Policy/#updating-inter-dependent-packages

Thanks!
znc-modpython installs fine, but pulls in python3.12-libs. Adding Python 3.13 blocker.

bugs.title: CVE-2024-39844 znc: remote code execution via modtcl [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2024-39844 znc: remote code execution via modtcl [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2024-39844 znc: remote code execution via modtcl

long_desc.thetext: In ZNC before 1.9.1, remote code execution can occur in modtcl via a KICK.

More information about this security flaw is available in the following bug:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2295622

Disclaimer: Community trackers are created by Red Hat Product Security team on a best effort basis. Package maintainers are required to ascertain if the flaw indeed affects their package, before starting the update process.

znc failed to build from source in Fedora rawhide/f41

https://koji.fedoraproject.org/koji/taskinfo?taskID=120789575


For details on the mass rebuild see:

https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Fedora_41_Mass_Rebuild
Please fix znc at your earliest convenience and set the bug's status to
ASSIGNED when you start fixing it. If the bug remains in NEW state for 8 weeks,
znc will be orphaned. Before branching of Fedora 42,
znc will be retired, if it still fails to build.

For more details on the FTBFS policy, please visit:
https://docs.fedoraproject.org/en-US/fesco/Fails_to_build_from_source_Fails_to_install/
